Sorry, what I meant was that if there was some concern
that since OPTIONS c=
an't be cached and it would be possible
that the metadata could be out of d=
ate by the time you
actually went to use the service, one possible way to d=
eal
with that is to redirect the OPTIONS call using a a 303,
which changes =
the call into a GET which could be made cachable.
An Expires: timestamp wou=
ld indicate how long that metadata is
gauranteed not to change.
 
 
- Jeff
=

	-----Original Message-----
	From: Seairth Jacobs [mailto:seairth@seairth.=
com] 
	Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 2:06 PM
	To: rest-discuss
	Subject=
: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
	
	
	MessageTrue, but I'm not =
seeing how this relates to my comments
below...
	
	---
	Seairth Jacobs
	sea=
irth@...
	
	
	----- Original Message -----
	From: Jeffrey Winter
	T=
o: Seairth Jacobs ; rest-discuss
	Sent: Wednesday, January 22, 2003 12:44 P=
M
	Subject: RE: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
	
	
	
	OPTIONS reque=
sts can respond with a "303 See Other" which could
	point to a cacheable st=
and-alone, metadata document.
	
	
	-----Original Message-----
	From: Seairt=
h Jacobs [mailto:seairth@...]
	Sent: Tuesday, January 21, 2003 9:50=
 PM
	To: rest-discuss
	Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST Resource Discovery
=
	
	
	From: "S. Mike Dierken" <mdierken@...>
	>
	> Huh. I thought I =
looked at OPTIONS and it wasn't
appropriate... don't know
	> what I was thi=
nking. Maybe I was looking only at what methods
were
	> allowed...
	> This =
seems like the best approach so far.
	>
	>
	> Here's the text from the RFC.=
 The only downside is responses
are not
	> cacheable.
	>
	> [deleted]
	>
	
=
	Hmm... When the RFC says the response is not cachable, I am
wondering if
	=
they have proxies, etc. in mind.  For the client, it seems that
caching
	wo=
uld have to be necessary unless the server could guarantee the
metadata in
=
	the OPTIONS response won't change for a certain period of time
(which is
	=
effectively caching).  Otherwise, the verb is potentially
useless...
	
	WRT=
 this thread, you would do an OPTIONS to a URI and get a
response back
	ind=
icating the POST/PUTable content-types.  Since there is no
guarantee that
	=
the allowable types are going to ba allowable a moment later
when you do
	y=
our actual POST/PUT, then it follows that it making a decision
on the
	retu=
rned metadata a day later would be little different than
making a
	decision=
 on it a second later.  At worst case, if the resource's
metadata
	changed =
between the time the OPTIONS response came back and the
client
	submitted a=
 request based on the returned metadata, the server
would/should
	return th=
e appropriate error.  In turn, this would prompt the
client to
	request the=
 OPTIONS again and see what has changed...
	
	---
	Seairth Jacobs
	seairth@=
seairth.com
